noun.description: A person's inherent qualities of mind and character.
examples: your sunny disposition has a way of rubbing off on those around you

noun.description: The way in which something is placed or arranged, especially in relation to other things.
examples: the plan need not be accurate so long as it shows the disposition of the rooms

noun.description: The action of distributing or transferring property or money to someone, in particular by bequest.
examples: this is a tax that affects the disposition of assets on death

noun.description: The power to deal with something as one pleases.
examples: if Napoleon had had railroads at his disposition, he would have been invincible

origin: Late Middle English: via Old French from Latin dispositio(n-), from disponere arrange (see dispose).
